Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: An Interactive 3D Game of Evolutionary Robotics for STEM-based Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project studies the problem of how to engage students in STEM (Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics) education through game-based learning in a Virtual Robotics computer game. In the game, students design, assemble and train virtual walking robots to compete against their peer robots to secure a seat on a virtual mission to Mars. The project analyses the effects of competition and collaboration on the learning and retention of key robotic control concepts. The project will produce a low-cost educational computer game, where far more U.S. middle schools and high schools students can learn about biomechanics, math, physics and computer algorithms through a robotic simulation game than is possible with current robot hardware approaches. The product provides the American educational system a solution to quickly engage students in STEM who might otherwise turn away. STEM field professions can lead to high paying jobs, which in turn can improve productivity and the economic landscape for America.

The project's education technology innovation is a cloud-based robot evolution game engine where students acting as a crowd can evolve the behavior of walking bi-pedal robots. The evolution of robot behavior happens on three levels: 1) the micro scale where an individual or small group of students evolves singular robot behaviors, 2) the mid-scale where groups exchange individual behaviors to form a behavior sequence to meet game level challenges. (For example, link a sequence of behaviors to stand, walk, jump, and turn to clear a section of obstacles and reach the prize goal), 3) the macro scale where the community evolves a cumulative set of behaviors through re-use and adoption of most efficient behaviors, discarding failed behaviors and creating new game level challenges. In particular, this project studies how individual and group learning is affected by adjusting the reward incentive, competitive motivation, novelty and surprise, and challenge level difficulty. During competition, the game gathers data regarding level of student learning and robot performance to answer two specific questions: a) do students learn more through small group or large group collaboration/competition, and b) are the students more engaged in small or large scale crowd-sourced environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report describes the research activities carried out, and the extent to which the objectives were met to create a robotics simulation game for STEM education. The report is written for a public audience.  The Xemo game can be dowloaded from our website at http://www.xemo.io/download.

The research and development activities were complete by a team of five people: the Principal Investigator (P.I.), two software game programmers, and two technical artists. The work was performed at the company’s office location in Burlington VT.

The project team created the product Xemo : Robot Simulator using the Unity 3D game engine and the Nvidia PhysX physics engine. All reseach objectives were in the original proposal where completed and are summarized here.

Evolution of Robot Behavior - the game includes an evolution engine that allows student players to evolve robot behavior based on certain goals such as walking to a target point.

Dynamic Behavior Switching - the student player creates multiple motion behaviors to mobilize the robot, then uses keystrokes to switch between behaviors such as walk, turn, jump and crawl.

Player Scripting - Xemo presents a visual interface to the player to control the robot. We also added a programming interface for direct control of the simulated robot to help teach coding skills.

Learn-More Videos - A set of tutorial videos were created to instruct the student player in how to create motions for the virtual robots. 

Robot Customization - The team created and tested the Xemo Robot Builder which enables students to build a virtual robot from parts, and then specify the strength and characteristics of the robot joints and motors.

Game Levels  - Sixteen game levels were created to challenge the student player to create increasingly complex motions for their virtual robots. Four different robot models were provided with different levels of difficulty.

MarketPlace - Xemo was exhibited at the 2016 World's Maker Faire in NYC, with over 1200 students and parents playing the game over the two-day weekend. Xemo is distributed through Steam (world's largest PC game distributor) and Itch.io, a distributor for independent games. Over 10,000 people have downloaded Xemo and requests continue to come in from across the USA and around the world to play Xemo in the classroom. The current version of Xemo is free-to-play. A pricing model will be put in place as the number of players in schools and at home grows.
